perturbation.original_text: "Applicable Laws" Shall mean all laws, rules and regulations regarding the manufacture, packaging, labeling, import, export, storage, distribution, representation, promotion, marketing and sale of the Products including but not limited to the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act of 1938, as amended ("FD&C Act") and the Controlled Substances Act, as amended (21 U.S.C. ยง801 et seq.), or as defined in attendant regulations promulgated under authorities granted by the FD&C Act, together with any equivalent laws, rules, regulations, codes or guidelines having effect in any jurisdiction in the Territory;
perturbation.changed_text: "Applicable Laws" Shall mean select laws, rules, and regulations that the Parties, at their sole discretion, deem relevant regarding the manufacture, packaging, labeling, import, export, storage, distribution, representation, promotion, marketing, and sale of the Products, potentially including the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act of 1938, as amended ("FD&C Act") and the Controlled Substances Act, as amended (21 U.S.C. ยง801 et seq.), but only if explicitly agreed upon in writing by both Parties. The term excludes any other laws, rules, regulations, codes, or guidelines, regardless of their effect in any jurisdiction within the Territory, unless specifically enumerated and agreed upon.
perturbation.explanation: The modified definition of 'Applicable Laws' introduces ambiguity by suggesting that not all relevant laws will automatically apply unless explicitly agreed upon. This contradicts the standard interpretation that all relevant laws and regulations are binding. This alteration can lead to disputes over which laws govern the agreement, potentially voiding the contract.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act)
perturbation.law_explanation: The modification contradicts the FD&C Act by suggesting that its applicability is discretionary, rather than mandatory. The FD&C Act mandates specific requirements for the safety and efficacy of drugs, and this clause could be interpreted as allowing the parties to selectively ignore these requirements.

perturbation.original_text: "Confidential Information" Means all confidential information, data and materials in whatever form disclosed by or on behalf of one Party or its Affiliates to the other Party or its Affiliates including, without limitation, the terms of this Agreement, data, formulae, unpublished patent disclosures, processes, protocols, marketing studies, sales information, specifications and know-how, (and, in the case of EKR's Confidential Information, EKR's marketing plans and EKR's sales forecasts), but excluding information which either Party can establish by written documentation: (i) at the time of disclosure, is in the public domain or is public knowledge; (ii) after disclosure, becomes part of the public domain by publication, except by breach of any obligation of confidentiality by a Party hereto or an Affiliate of such Party; (iii) was already in its possession at the time of its receipt and was not acquired directly or indirectly from the other Party or its Affiliates; or (iv) received from Third Parties who were lawfully entitled to disclose such information;
perturbation.changed_text: "Confidential Information" Means information one party chooses to treat as confidential. There is no required form, but the receiving party must acknowledge receipt of the confidential notice. Excluding information: (i) that the receiving party subjectively believes is publicly available, (ii) which becomes public through any means whatsoever, (iii) that the receiving party can show it possessed, or (iv) that it received from anyone else.
perturbation.explanation: The modified definition dramatically broadens the exceptions to confidential information, undermining the enforceability of the confidentiality clause. The original text's reliance on 'written documentation' to prove exceptions is removed, replaced by subjective belief and any means of public disclosure. This conflicts with established trade secret and confidentiality laws.
perturbation.law_citation: Varies by state; example: California Uniform Trade Secrets Act, Cal. Civ. Code ยง 3426
perturbation.law_explanation: The modified definition contradicts the UTSA, which requires reasonable efforts to maintain secrecy for information to be considered a trade secret. The revised definition's broad exceptions allow for easy disclosure and undermines the 'reasonable efforts' standard, potentially stripping information of its trade secret status.

perturbation.original_text: 10.6 Insurance. Each Party shall maintain, at its own cost, comprehensive product liability insurance, general commercial liability insurance and business interruption insurance at a level which is reasonable and customary taking into account the nature of the Product but which shall have combined limits of not less than $[**] per occurrence. Such insurance shall be with a reputable insurance company and where reasonably possible (taking into account the availability of such insurance) shall be maintained for not less than [**] ([**]) years following the expiry or termination of this Agreement. During the Term, neither Party shall do or omit to do any act, matter or thing which could prejudice or render voidable any such insurance. Each Party will provide to the other Party evidence of its insurance and thirty (30) days prior written notice of any cancellation of its coverage or reduction in coverage from the requirements stated herein.
perturbation.changed_text: 10.6 Insurance. Each Party may, at its sole discretion, maintain product liability insurance. The level of insurance, if any, is to be determined by each party independently, but in no case shall it be seen as a requirement for conducting business under this agreement. Proof of insurance and notification of changes are optional, as determined by each party.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause mandates insurance coverage. The modified clause makes insurance optional, contradicting standard business practice and legal expectations regarding product liability. This shift introduces significant risk and questions the enforceability of other liability-related clauses in the contract.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied Covenant of Good Faith and Fair Dealing (Common Law)
perturbation.law_citation: Varies by state; generally recognized principle of contract law
perturbation.law_explanation: While not a specific statute, the modification potentially violates the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing. By making insurance optional, a party could act in a way that undermines the other party's reasonable expectations under the contract, especially concerning risk mitigation and liability protection. This is a principle recognized in most jurisdictions of the United States.
